expanded_description: Simple machines are basic mechanical devices that change the magnitude or direction of forces, making work easier. While they cannot reduce the amount of work required (energy conservation), they can trade force for distance, allowing smaller forces to accomplish tasks that would otherwise require larger forces.

core_concept.principle: A simple machine is a basic mechanical device that changes the magnitude or direction of an applied force. The six classical simple machines are: lever, wheel and axle, pulley, inclined plane, wedge, and screw. Key principle: Simple machines redistribute work—they can reduce force required but only by increasing the distance over which force acts. Work in = Work out (ideally): $F_{\text{in}} \cdot d_{\text{in}} = F_{\text{out}} \cdot d_{\text{out}}$. Trading force for distance (or vice versa) makes tasks achievable with available force.
core_concept.explanation: Simple machines are fundamental tools that have been used for thousands of years. They don't create energy or reduce the work required—that would violate conservation of energy. Instead, they make work easier by changing how force is applied. The core insight: Work = Force × Distance. If work is conserved (ideal machine, no friction), reducing force required means increasing distance traveled, and vice versa. Example: Ramp (inclined plane) allows lifting heavy object to height with smaller force than lifting straight up. The trade-off: must push object along longer path (ramp length > vertical height). Work is the same ($W = mgh$ regardless of path for conservative forces), but force is reduced. Simple machines enable humans to accomplish tasks beyond their direct strength: Lever can lift car (small force × long distance = large force × short distance). Pulley system can lift heavy loads with reduced force. Ramp allows wheeling refrigerator up stairs instead of lifting. All complex machines are combinations of simple machines: Car jack (screw + lever), bicycle (wheel and axle + lever + gears), crane (pulleys + levers). Understanding simple machines reveals: (1) How mechanical advantage works (force amplification via distance trade). (2) Why no machine can do more work output than work input (conservation of energy). (3) How real machines lose energy to friction (efficiency < 100%). (4) Design principles for tools and machines throughout history and modern engineering. Simple machines are not just historical curiosities—they remain essential in modern technology, from door hinges (lever) to car transmissions (gears—modified wheel and axle) to wheelchair ramps (inclined plane).

sections.introduction: The six classical simple machines are fundamental mechanical devices, each with distinct mechanisms for changing forces.

key_concept.definition: The six classical simple machines are: (1) Lever—rigid bar pivoting on fulcrum. (2) Wheel and axle—wheel attached to axle, rotating together. (3) Pulley—rope over wheel to change force direction or magnitude. (4) Inclined plane—flat surface at angle to horizontal. (5) Wedge—moving inclined plane (two inclined planes back-to-back). (6) Screw—inclined plane wrapped around cylinder. All other machines are combinations of these basic six.
key_concept.context: These six were identified by ancient Greek engineers and Renaissance scientists as the fundamental building blocks of all machines. Modern analysis confirms they represent the basic ways to manipulate forces mechanically.

classifications.value: Rigid bar rotating around a fixed point (fulcrum)
characteristics: Three parts: fulcrum (pivot), effort (applied force), load (resistance)
classifications.behavior: Torque about fulcrum determines balance. Longer effort arm → greater mechanical advantage.

examples.process: First-class lever (fulcrum between effort and load)
examples.explanation: Examples: Seesaw, crowbar, scissors, pliers. Fulcrum in middle. Effort and load on opposite sides. Can change direction (push down, load goes up). Mechanical advantage depends on arm length ratio. Long effort arm, short load arm → large mechanical advantage (force amplification). Example: Crowbar—push down on long end (effort), short end lifts load. MA can be 10+ (small force × long distance = large force × short distance).

examples.process: Second-class lever (load between fulcrum and effort)
examples.explanation: Examples: Wheelbarrow, nutcracker, bottle opener, door (hinges are fulcrum). Load between fulcrum and effort. Always provides mechanical advantage >1 (effort arm always longer than load arm). Doesn't reverse direction. Example: Wheelbarrow—wheel is fulcrum, load in bin between wheel and handles. Effort at handles (long arm) lifts heavy load (short arm from wheel). Can lift several times your pushing force.

examples.process: Third-class lever (effort between fulcrum and load)
examples.explanation: Examples: Tweezers, fishing rod, human arm (elbow joint). Effort between fulcrum and load. Mechanical advantage <1 (effort arm shorter than load arm—force disadvantage). Purpose: Increase speed and range of motion (distance advantage). Example: Arm lifting object—elbow (fulcrum), biceps pulls (effort, close to elbow), hand (load, far from elbow). Must exert large force, but small biceps motion → large hand motion (speed multiplier).

classifications.value: Large wheel attached to smaller axle, both rotating together
characteristics: Force applied to wheel, output at axle (or vice versa)
Mechanical advantage = wheel radius / axle radius
classifications.behavior: Torque transferred between wheel and axle. Large wheel × small force = small axle × large force.

examples.process: Force on wheel, output at axle (MA > 1)
examples.explanation: Examples: Screwdriver, door knob, car steering wheel, wrench. Turning large wheel with small force → axle exerts large force. MA = $r_{\text{wheel}}/r_{\text{axle}}$ (radius ratio). Example: Screwdriver handle 2 cm radius, shaft 3 mm radius. MA = 20/3 ≈ 6.7. Turning handle with 10 N → screw feels 67 N. Larger handle (larger wheel) → greater MA → easier to turn tight screws.

examples.process: Force on axle, output at wheel (MA < 1, speed advantage)
examples.explanation: Examples: Bicycle wheels, car wheels, Ferris wheel. Small force at axle → smaller force at wheel, but wheel moves faster/farther. Purpose: Convert high-force small-distance into low-force large-distance (speed multiplier). Example: Bicycle—pedals turn axle (small circle), wheel (large circle) rotates. Pedals move small distance, wheel rim moves large distance → bicycle goes far. Trade force for speed.

Gears are toothed wheels and axles meshing together. Small gear driving large gear: Increases force, decreases speed (MA > 1). Large gear driving small gear: Decreases force, increases speed (MA < 1). Example: Car transmission—different gear ratios for different force/speed needs. Low gear (small wheel to large): High force for acceleration/hills. High gear (large to small): High speed for cruising.

classifications.value: Rope over wheel to redirect force or create mechanical advantage
characteristics: Multiple pulleys (block and tackle): MA = number of supporting ropes
classifications.behavior: Each supporting rope segment shares the load. More segments → greater MA.

examples.explanation: Pulley attached to ceiling/support. Rope over pulley. Pull down, load goes up. Direction change advantage: Can pull down using body weight (easier than pushing up). No mechanical advantage: Force in = force out. Use: Flagpoles, window blinds, wells. Example: Lift 50 N flag, must pull down with 50 N. Easier direction (pull down) but same force.

Pulley attached to load, moves with load. Rope fixed at top, goes under movable pulley, pulled upward. Two rope segments support load → each carries half the load. Pull with F, load experiences 2F. MA = 2. Example: Lift 100 N load—rope has two segments supporting it. Each carries 50 N. Pull upward with 50 N, load rises (100 N supported). Trade-off: Must pull rope 2 meters to lift load 1 meter.

examples.process: Block and tackle (multiple pulleys, MA = n)
examples.explanation: Combination of fixed and movable pulleys. Multiple rope segments support load. MA = number of supporting rope segments. Example: 4-rope system—MA = 4. Lift 400 N load with 100 N force. Pull 4 m of rope to lift load 1 m. Complex systems can have MA = 10+ (lift 1000 N with 100 N), but must pull huge lengths of rope. Used in: Construction cranes, sailing ships, theater stage systems, engine hoists.

classifications.value: Flat surface at angle to horizontal—ramp
characteristics: Reduces force needed to lift by increasing distance
Trade vertical lifting for sloped pushing
classifications.behavior: Gravity component along plane is less than full weight. Longer/shallower ramp → less force needed.

examples.explanation: Push object up ramp instead of lifting straight up. Force needed: $F = W \sin\theta$ where $W$ is weight, $\theta$ is ramp angle (from horizontal). Small angle → small $\sin\theta$ → small force. Distance along ramp = height / $\sin\theta$ (longer than vertical height). Example: Lift 200 N box to height 2 m. Vertical: Must apply 200 N over 2 m. Ramp (20° angle, 5.8 m long): Force needed ≈ 200 × sin20° ≈ 68 N over 5.8 m. Work same: 200 × 2 = 400 J = 68 × 5.8 ≈ 394 J (close, with rounding). Much easier force!

Wheelchair ramps: Access buildings without stairs. Building codes specify maximum slope (typically 1:12—rise 1 m per 12 m length) for safe wheelchair use. Roads on mountains: Switchbacks (zigzag) rather than straight up. Increases distance but reduces grade (slope)—vehicles can climb with available power. Loading docks: Ramps for rolling heavy items into trucks. Stairs are discontinuous inclined planes (steps approximate smooth ramp).

classifications.value: Moving inclined plane—two inclined planes back-to-back
characteristics: Converts small motion into large splitting force
Short thick wedge (blunt) vs long thin wedge (sharp)
classifications.behavior: Small force over long distance (driving wedge) → large force over short distance (splitting).

examples.explanation: Examples: Axe, knife, chisel, saw teeth. Thin wedge (small angle) penetrates easily (sharp). Converts forward motion into sideways splitting force. Axe: Swing axe (force along blade direction, long distance). Blade wedge forces wood fibers apart (large force, short distance—width of blade). Work in (swing) ≈ work out (splitting), but force multiplied. Sharp blade (thin wedge) easier to insert, less friction. Blunt blade (thick wedge) requires more force.

Nails: Wedge shape (pointed) allows easier penetration into wood. Zipper: Slider contains wedge that separates or joins teeth. Door stop: Wedge under door converts horizontal force (pushing wedge under) into large vertical normal force (holds door). Shims: Thin wedges for leveling, spacing, or tightening. Small thickness change over long wedge creates large force.

Plow blade: Wedge turns soil aside (small horizontal motion → large sideways soil displacement). Snowplow: Similar principle—clears path by pushing snow to sides. Teeth (incisors): Wedge-shaped for cutting food. Molars are different shape (grinding, not wedging).

classifications.value: Inclined plane wrapped around cylinder—continuous ramp
characteristics: Converts rotational force into linear force
MA = circumference / pitch (pitch = distance between threads)
classifications.behavior: Turning screw (long circular distance) → small linear motion → large force. Gentle slope → large MA.

examples.explanation: Screw threads are inclined plane spiraling around shaft. Turning screw one revolution: moves forward one pitch (thread spacing). Gentle thread slope (fine threads, small pitch) → large MA → large clamping force. Example: Bolt—diameter 1 cm (circumference ≈ 3.14 cm), pitch 1 mm. One full turn: travel 3.14 cm around, advance 1 mm. MA ≈ 31.4. Turn with 10 N → bolt exerts 314 N clamping force. Fine threads (smaller pitch) → even higher MA → tighter clamping.

Car jack (screw jack): Turn handle (long lever) rotating screw. Screw drives lifting mechanism. Very high MA—small hand force lifts car (thousands of newtons). Vise: Screw mechanism converts rotation into clamping force. Clamps objects tightly with modest hand force. Wine press, book press: Screw converts rotation into squeezing force. Can generate enormous pressure for extracting juice, compressing materials.

Micrometer: Precision measuring tool using fine-pitch screw. Rotating thimble (known circumference) moves spindle tiny distance (from pitch). Can measure to 0.01 mm accuracy. Telescope focus, microscope focus: Fine thread screw for precise positioning. Camera tripod height adjustment: Threaded screw mechanism. Adjustable piano stool, height-adjustable desks: Screw-based vertical positioning.

sections.section_title: How Simple Machines Work: Force and Distance Trade-Off
sections.introduction: All simple machines work by the same fundamental principle: trading force for distance (or vice versa) while conserving work.

key_concept.definition: Work-Energy Principle for Simple Machines (ideal, no friction): Work input = Work output. $W_{\text{in}} = W_{\text{out}}$. $F_{\text{in}} \cdot d_{\text{in}} = F_{\text{out}} \cdot d_{\text{out}}$. If output force increased ($F_{\text{out}} > F_{\text{in}}$), then output distance decreased ($d_{\text{out}} < d_{\text{in}}$) proportionally. Mechanical advantage: $MA = \frac{F_{\text{out}}}{F_{\text{in}}} = \frac{d_{\text{in}}}{d_{\text{out}}$ (ideal machine). Cannot get more work out than work in—energy conservation forbids it.
key_concept.context: This is why simple machines don't 'create' energy or reduce work—they redistribute it. The advantage is psychological and practical: smaller force feels easier even though we apply it over longer distance/time.

principles.statement: In ideal (frictionless) machine: Work in = Work out. $F_{\text{in}} d_{\text{in}} = F_{\text{out}} d_{\text{out}}$. Energy input = Energy output. No energy created or destroyed, just transformed.
principles.application: Calculate unknowns from work conservation. If force reduced 5×, distance must increase 5×.
principles.example: Lever lifting 500 N rock using 100 N force: Work to lift rock 0.2 m: $W_{\text{out}} = 500 × 0.2 = 100$ J. Work conservation: $W_{\text{in}} = 100$ J. Distance to push lever: $d_{\text{in}} = W_{\text{in}}/F_{\text{in}} = 100/100 = 1$ m. Force reduced 5× (500 → 100 N), distance increased 5× (0.2 → 1 m). Same work.

principles.statement: Simple machines trade force for distance or vice versa: Increase output force → Must increase input distance (force advantage, distance disadvantage). Increase output distance → Must increase input force (distance advantage, force disadvantage). Cannot have both force AND distance advantage simultaneously (would violate energy conservation).
principles.application: Understand that 'easier' means less force but more distance/time. Not less work.
principles.example: Ramp vs stairs: Ramp: Gentle slope, small force needed, long distance walked. Stairs: Steep, larger force each step, short horizontal distance. Wheelchair ramp must be very long (1:12 slope) to keep force manageable. Stairs acceptable for walking humans (can exert larger forces in steps). Both reach same height, do same work, but distribute force/distance differently.

principles.statement: Machines don't reduce work, so why do they help? Answer: Humans have force limits but not strict distance/time limits (within reason). Machine trades abundant resource (distance/time) for scarce resource (force capability). Makes task achievable with available force, even if takes longer/farther.
principles.application: Choose machine when force is limiting factor. Accept distance/time increase as acceptable trade.
principles.example: Lifting 200 kg refrigerator (weight ~2000 N): Direct lift: Impossible for most people (exceeds maximum force capability ~500-800 N). Ramp: 20° angle, need ~700 N force (achievable) but must push 5.8 m instead of lifting 2 m (more distance, but possible). Or, use pulley system: MA = 4, need 500 N but pull 8 m of rope (lift only 2 m). Machine enables task by reducing peak force below human capability, accepting distance increase. Task goes from impossible to possible, even though work is the same.

principles.statement: Real machines have friction, deformation, heat losses: $W_{\text{out}} < W_{\text{in}}$ always (efficiency < 100%). Extra work needed to overcome friction, does NOT appear as useful output—becomes heat. Must do MORE input work than ideal calculation suggests.
principles.application: Efficiency $\eta = W_{\text{out}}/W_{\text{in}}$ typically 50-95% for simple machines. Account for losses.
principles.example: Inclined plane with friction: Ideal: Push 68 N to lift 200 N object on 20° ramp. Real (μ = 0.3): Friction force ~60 N opposes motion. Total force needed ~130 N (not 68 N). Efficiency ~50% (about half your work goes to overcoming friction, half to lifting). Must do double the work compared to ideal. Why oil/grease important: Reduces friction → increases efficiency → closer to ideal machine performance.

worked_examples.title: Lever Work Conservation
worked_examples.problem: A first-class lever has effort arm 1.5 m and load arm 0.3 m. You push down on effort side with 80 N force, moving it 0.4 m. Find: (a) distance load moves, (b) force on load (ideal machine).

step_by_step.explanation: Ideal machine: $W_{\text{out}} = W_{\text{in}} = 32$ J. But we don't know output force yet. Alternative: Use lever arm ratio. Effort arm : load arm = 1.5 : 0.3 = 5 : 1. Effort moves 5× farther than load. $d_{\text{out}} = d_{\text{in}}/5 = 0.4/5$
Force increased 5× (80 → 400 N). Distance decreased 5× (0.4 → 0.08 m). Product (work) constant: 80 × 0.4 = 400 × 0.08 = 32 J ✓

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Load moves 0.08 m = 8 cm, (b) Load force = 400 N
worked_examples.concept_applied: Work conservation: Input work = output work. Force increased → distance decreased proportionally. Trade-off maintains constant work.

worked_examples.title: Inclined Plane Work Calculation
worked_examples.problem: A 50 kg box (weight 490 N) must be raised 3 m. Compare work using: (a) vertical lift, (b) ramp 10 m long at 17.5° angle (sin 17.5° ≈ 0.3). Assume frictionless.

step_by_step.explanation: Force needed (parallel to ramp): $F = W \sin\theta = 490 × 0.3 = 147$ N (much less than 490 N!). Distance along ramp: 10 m (given). Work: $W = F \cdot d = 147 × 10 = 1470$ J

Same work both methods (1470 J)—energy conservation for conservative forces (gravity). Ramp advantage: Force reduced from 490 N to 147 N (3.3× smaller—within human capability). Distance increased from 3 m to 10 m (3.3× longer). Trade-off makes lifting possible with smaller force.

If μ = 0.2: Friction ≈ 0.2 × mg cos θ ≈ 0.2 × 470 ≈ 94 N. Total force needed: 147 + 94 = 241 N. Work: 241 × 10 = 2410 J (more than ideal 1470 J). Efficiency = 1470/2410 ≈ 61%. Friction costs extra work—why ramps often have wheels/rollers.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Vertical: 1470 J (490 N force, 3 m). (b) Ramp: 1470 J (147 N force, 10 m). Same work, different force-distance distribution.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Inclined plane trades force for distance. Work conserved (ideal). Real friction adds extra work required.

worked_examples.title: Pulley System Mechanical Advantage
worked_examples.problem: A block and tackle has 4 rope segments supporting the load. You pull with 120 N force through 8 m of rope. Find: (a) load that can be lifted (ideal), (b) height load rises.

step_by_step.explanation: MA = number of supporting rope segments = 4

4 segments share the load → each shortens equally when load rises. Pull 8 m of rope → total shortening = 8 m distributed among 4 segments. Each segment shortens 8/4 = 2 m → load rises 2 m. Or, work conservation: $W_{\text{in}} = 120 × 8 = 960$ J. $W_{\text{out}} = 480 × h = 960$ → $h = 2$ m
Force multiplied 4× (120 → 480 N). Distance divided 4× (8 → 2 m). Work constant: 120 × 8 = 480 × 2 = 960 J ✓

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Can lift 480 N load, (b) Load rises 2 m
worked_examples.concept_applied: Pulley MA = number of supporting segments. Force multiplied by MA, distance divided by MA. Work conserved.

image.alt: Diagram showing same work with different force-distance combinations: high force×short distance = low force×long distance
image.caption: Force-distance trade-off: $F_{\text{in}} d_{\text{in}} = F_{\text{out}} d_{\text{out}}$. Reduce force → increase distance (or vice versa). Work conserved.

sections.introduction: Most useful machines are combinations of simple machines. Understanding how simple machines combine reveals how complex devices work.

categories.description: Combinations of two or more simple machines working together.

examples.explanation: Multiple simple machines combined: Wheels (wheel and axle—both wheels and pedal crank). Pedals (lever—foot pushes pedal arm, crank rotates). Chain and sprockets (wheel and axle + modified pulley—transfers rotation). Gears (wheel and axle—different sized sprockets change MA and speed). Brakes (lever—hand squeezes brake lever, cable pulls brake pads). Handlebars (lever—turning force amplified). Total MA: Product of individual MAs. Example: Front sprocket 50 teeth, rear 25 teeth → ratio 2:1. Pedal crank 17 cm, wheel radius 35 cm → ratio ~1:2. Combined: For pedaling, distance advantage (wheel moves farther per pedal stroke). Overall system optimized for human power and speed.

Scissor jack: Lever + screw. Turn handle (lever increases turning force) → rotates screw → screw drives mechanism (inclined plane wrapped around cylinder converts rotation to linear lift) → scissors mechanism (levers) lifts car. Very high total MA—small hand force lifts car (10,000+ N). Hydraulic jack: Lever (handle) + piston/cylinder (hydraulic force multiplication). Small piston × large force = large piston × small force (Pascal's principle). Can lift heavy loads with small pump handle force.

Wheel and axle + second-class lever. Wheel: Reduces friction (rolling instead of dragging). Lever: Wheel is fulcrum, load between wheel and handles. Handles are effort. MA from lever arm ratio ~2-3. Easy to move heavy loads (several times your lifting force) over distance.

Car transmission: Multiple gear pairs (wheels and axles). Different ratios for different conditions. Low gear: Small wheel drives large wheel → high torque (force), low speed. For starting, climbing hills. High gear: Large wheel drives small wheel → low torque, high speed. For cruising. Clutch/shift mechanism: Connects different gear pairs as needed. Automatic transmission: Planetary gears provide continuous variable ratio. Complex compound machine with dozens of simple machine elements.

categories.description: Simple machines in ancient and medieval technology.

examples.explanation: Likely used: Ramps (inclined planes) to raise massive stone blocks—reduces force needed, increases distance. Levers and rollers to position blocks precisely. Estimates: Ramp might be 1:10 slope (rise 1 m per 10 m length). To lift block to 50 m height: Ramp ~500 m long (spiral around pyramid). Force reduced ~10×, but must move block 500 m instead of lifting 50 m. Achievable with available workforce, though enormous effort. Debate continues on exact methods, but simple machines central to construction.

Archimedes (c. 287-212 BC): Studied levers, pulleys, screws. Famous quote: 'Give me a place to stand and I will move the Earth' (with long enough lever). Archimedes screw: Pump water uphill using screw (inclined plane). Still used in modern sewage plants. Roman siege weapons: Catapults, ballistae using levers and torsion springs. Aqueducts: Minimal slope (inclined plane) allows gravity to move water over long distances (sometimes 50+ km). Roman roads: Graded to avoid steep slopes—easier travel for carts.

Treadwheel cranes: Large wheel humans walk inside (like hamster wheel). Wheel and axle + pulley system. People walking in wheel (input force) → Rotation amplified by large wheel radius → Pulley system lifts heavy stones (cathedrals, castles). MA could reach 30-50. Few people could lift tons of stone. Enabled construction of Gothic cathedrals with massive stone vaulting.

categories.description: Simple machines remain essential in modern technology.

examples.explanation: Excavator: Hydraulic cylinders (pistons—modified lever/screw combination) provide huge forces. Boom and arm (levers) multiply force and reach. Bucket (wedge) penetrates ground. Treads (wheel and axle + inclined wedges for grip). Crane: Pulleys (block and tackle) lift loads. Boom (lever) extends reach. Hydraulics control positioning. Can lift 100+ tons with these combined simple machines. Forklift: Hydraulic lift (piston) + lever system raises forks. Wheels provide mobility.

Scissors: Two levers (first-class) + two wedges (blades). Squeeze handles (effort arms) → Blades close with more force (load arms shorter) → Wedges cut material. Pliers: Similar—lever arms multiply gripping force. Bottle opener: Lever (first or second class depending on type) pries cap off. Can opener: Wheel and axle (turning knob) rotates wedge (cutting wheel) that pierces lid, plus lever to provide downward force. Screwdriver: Wheel and axle—handle (wheel) rotates shaft (axle). Large handle makes turning screws easier.

Wheelchair ramps: Inclined plane—essential for accessibility. Building codes mandate maximum slopes (1:12 or 1:20). Longer ramp (more distance) but manageable force for wheelchair user. Lever-style door handles (vs round knobs): Easier for people with limited hand strength/dexterity. Lever MA helps. Grab bars: Levers providing support—person pulls on long arm, force transmitted to short arm anchored to wall. Adjustable hospital beds: Screw mechanisms for precise positioning, hydraulics for lifting. Prosthetic limbs: Levers (joints), springs (energy storage/return), modern versions with motors and microprocessors but still using simple machine principles.

Robot arms: Multiple rotational joints (wheel and axle), each with motors and gears (wheel and axle combinations). Lever arms provide reach and positioning. End effectors use grippers (levers), drills (screws), cutting tools (wedges). CNC machines: Screws (lead screws, ball screws) convert rotation to precise linear motion. Cut metal, plastic to micron precision. Assembly lines: Conveyor belts (wheels and axles), hydraulic presses (lever + piston), robotic pick-and-place (levers and grippers). All based on simple machines combined with motors, sensors, computers.

image.alt: Diagrams of bicycle, car jack, and excavator showing component simple machines labeled
image.caption: Compound machines: Bicycle (wheels, levers, gears), Jack (screw + levers), Excavator (levers + hydraulics + wedge). Complex devices built from simple machines.

summary: Simple machines are basic mechanical devices that change force magnitude or direction: lever, wheel and axle, pulley, inclined plane, wedge, and screw. All complex machines are combinations of these six. Core principle: Simple machines trade force for distance (or vice versa) while conserving work (ideally): $W_{\text{in}} = W_{\text{out}}$ or $F_{\text{in}} d_{\text{in}} = F_{\text{out}} d_{\text{out}}$. Cannot reduce work required (violates energy conservation), but can reduce force needed by accepting increased distance. Lever: Rigid bar pivoting on fulcrum. Three classes: (1st) fulcrum between effort and load—changes direction, variable MA; (2nd) load between fulcrum and effort—always MA > 1, doesn't reverse direction; (3rd) effort between fulcrum and load—MA < 1, provides speed/distance advantage. MA = effort arm length / load arm length. Wheel and axle: Large wheel attached to smaller axle, rotating together. Force on wheel → torque multiplication at axle (MA = $r_{\text{wheel}}/r_{\text{axle}} > 1$). Force on axle → speed multiplication at wheel (MA < 1). Examples: screwdriver, steering wheel, gears. Pulley: Rope over wheel. Fixed pulley (MA = 1, changes direction only). Movable pulley (MA = 2, two rope segments support load). Block and tackle (MA = number of supporting rope segments, can reach high MA). Trade-off: pull more rope to lift load shorter distance. Inclined plane: Ramp reduces lifting force by increasing distance. Force needed = $W \sin\theta$ where $\theta$ is ramp angle. Shallow angle → small force, long ramp. Work same as vertical lift: $mgh$. Applications: ramps, roads, wheelchair access. Wedge: Moving inclined plane (two inclined planes back-to-back). Converts small forward force over long distance into large splitting force over short distance. Examples: axe, knife, chisel, plow. Screw: Inclined plane wrapped around cylinder. Converts rotation (long circular distance) into linear motion (short distance). Very high MA possible (fine threads). Examples: bolts, jacks, vise, micrometer. Force-distance trade-off: Fundamental to all simple machines. Reduce force → must increase distance proportionally. Work conserved: $F_{\text{small}} \times d_{\text{large}} = F_{\text{large}} \times d_{\text{small}}$. Makes tasks achievable with available force (trade abundant resource—distance/time—for scarce resource—force). Real machines have friction: Efficiency < 100% always. Must do more input work than ideal to overcome friction (becomes heat). Typical efficiencies 50-95% for simple machines. Lubrication reduces friction, increases efficiency. Compound machines: Combinations of simple machines. Examples: bicycle (wheels, levers, gears), car jack (screw + lever), excavator (hydraulic pistons + levers + wedge). Total MA = product of individual MAs. Modern applications: Construction (cranes, excavators—pulleys, levers, hydraulics), Hand tools (scissors, pliers—levers and wedges), Accessibility (ramps, lever handles—inclines, levers), Manufacturing (robots, CNC—screws, wheels, levers). Historical importance: Egyptian pyramids (ramps to lift blocks), Greek engineering (Archimedes studied levers/pulleys/screws), Medieval construction (treadwheel cranes—wheels, pulleys), Roman aqueducts (gentle inclines transport water). Understanding simple machines reveals: How to accomplish tasks with limited force (trade distance), Why machines can't create energy (conservation law), How complex devices work (combinations of simple elements), Design principles for tools and machines throughout history and modern engineering.
